DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said rapid progress is being made in trade discussions with China and we're getting very close to trade deal, but added it is not yet made and could be announced in the next 4 weeks, maybe more or less. Furthermore, US President Trump said he will hold a summit with Chinese President XI in Washington if there is a deal and that he will discuss tariffs with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He, while he cited tariffs as well as IP theft when asked about sticking points. (Newswires)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He said we have currently made good progress in trade discussions, while US Trade Representative Lighthizer also noted that plenty of headway was made and the US has a good partner in China's Vice Premier Liu He but added there are still major, major issues remaining. (Newswires)

RBI cut the Repurchase Rate and Reverse Repo Rate by 25bps each to 6.00% and 5.75% as expected. The central bank maintained a neutral stance although one member wanted to change stance to “accommodative”, while the RBI said output gap remains negative and domestic economy is facing headwinds on a global front. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed India at BBB-, Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK House of Lords reportedly will try to get the second reading of the Cooper-Letwin completed tonight and the remaining stages on Monday, according to The Times' Esther Webber. (Twitter)

A letter from UK PM May's government to EU's Tusk requesting for an A50 extension is being drafted, with current debate in Cabinet on how long the extension should be. (The Guardian)

EU Commission’s Katainen said a hard Brexit is becoming increasingly possible as we do not know what the alternatives are, while he added if there is no WA then that means there are few options available. (Newswires)

ECB Minutes noted that concerns were voiced regarding the effect of persistently low rates on bank profitability & intermediation, while it added that growth returning to potential through the projection horizon may be optimistic. (Newswires) 

US

US President Trump said he is giving Mexico a 1yr warning and that if that does not stop the illegal drugs coming in, US will tariff Mexican goods including cars and close the border. President Trump later commented that there would be a 25% tariff on car imports from Mexico if he decides to apply tariffs but also said that Mexico has done good regarding the border during past 4 days, while he added that he did not say the border would stay open for a year but that he would place tariffs first. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (non-voter, dove) said he does not see a rate cut this year or next year and is still in "wait and see mode", while he expects one rate hike "at most" in 2019 and one in 2020. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester (non-voter, hawk) said she is biased to keeping rates where they are or moving them up a bit despite downside risks, while she added that it is possible FFR may need to move higher if the economy performs in line with Fed scenarios but also commented it is possible that the Fed is done with hikes for this cycle. (Newswires)

US President Trump confirmed he has recommended Herman Cain to the Fed board. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

Constellation Brands (STZ) outperformed on Thursday after reporting a beat on top and bottom line estimates as well as announcing the divesting of some of its wine and spirits assets, investors looked over its gloomy guidance. Tesla (TSLA) nosedived after disappointing results from its Q1 deliveries. Facebook (FB) caught a bid on the open following an upgrade at Guggenheim. Boeing (BA) benefitted from a note at Morgan Stanley saying that the worst case scenario is “off the table”; Morgan Stanley also caused Micron (MU) to dip lower, citing street estimates as too optimistic. Cowen analysts gave tailwinds to Netflix (NFLX), citing it as in a prime spot, and also Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), citing partnerships and digitalisation that will fuel growth. Office Depot (ODP) fell off a cliff on the back of a disappointing earnings outlook. Take-Two (TTWO) came under pressure as investors didn’t take to kindly to the announcement it would launch its Borderlands 3 videogame exclusively on the Epic Games store. SPX +0.21% at 2879, NDX -0.06% at 7541, DJI +0.64% at 26385.

According to the CME’s Fedwatch tool, the implied chance of a rate cut in 2019 still stands at over 50%. While this has certainly edged lower from periods in the last month where the chance was around 75% (implied by money market pricing), it still seems at odds with comments from Fed officials, who have generally been upbeat about the economy while acknowledging its slowing; many others have noted that as the tax-cut high fizzles out, growth was always expected to normalise. But there is still a lack of high profile Fed officials talking about cuts. Mester and Harker today both intimated the next move could be higher (non-voters). Perhaps the pricing is a result of comments from nominee Moore, who this week called for an immediate 50bps rate cut, and NEC director Kudlow, who echoed Moore’s remarks; then there is Trump's own preference for lower rates, and the criticism he often fires in the direction of the Fed. The latest on the Fed BOG, is that Trump is mulling nominating Herman Cain, who is a fan of former Fed chair Greenspan. Tomorrow’s payrolls data will be an important catalyst, but for different reasons than the Street may report: SocGen’s strategist Kit Juckes argues that a weak number could put the cat among the pigeons without telling us anything new, while a strong number wouldn’t be surprising unless it challenged the conclusions from other indicators. The key, Juckes says, is whether we are in an intra-cycle turn, like in 2016, or whether we are at the start of the end of the cycle; Juckes says he is in the latter camp, though notes that in 2006, the S&P 500 didn’t peak till later in the year, while IG CDS didn’t reach its tightest until 2007, suggesting there could be more juice in this market. In terms of the curve, action was very thin ahead of payrolls on Friday, and at settlement, curve spreads were a touch narrower. US T-Note futures (M9) settled 1+ higher at 123-17+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 4 April 2019: Traders anticipate trade announcement; markets subdued ahead of NFP
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US MARKET WRAP 4 April 2019: Traders anticipate trade announcement; markets subdued ahead of NFP

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities mixed, dollar up, treasuries flat, crude mixed.

* REAR VIEW: US-China talks in the “end-game”; Initial jobless hit cyclical low; Fed’s Mester, Harker favour wait and see, say next move could be up; geopolitical tensions rise in Libya again.

* AHEAD: US Nonfarm payrolls; Canada payrolls; German Industrial Output; Fed's Bostic; ECB's Mersch.

 

* TRADE: As US-China trade talks ramped up on Thursday, where Trump himself was reported to have attended meetings, there  were mixed reports on what has been achieved: some expected a date to be set on a meeting between Xi/Trump, though this might not be forthcoming today (unless Trump changes his mind, reports say). However, the narrative of the two super-states making progress was maintained, with Commerce official Myron Brilliant stating that talks were in the “end-game” but a final deal had still not been reached. President Trump recycled his regular optimism saying that talks were “coming along well” and that the deal must be a great one, otherwise the US will not be doing it. More specifically and as expected, Trump said the deal must include action on IP theft and technology transfers, as well as adding that China will be purchasing a lot of products from the US. Elsewhere, fears of an imminent shutting of the US-Mexico border were put at ease, where Trump said he would be giving his southern neighbour a one year period to stop the inflow of illegal drugs into the US, and if Trump is still not satisfied he said he would initiate tariffs on goods – including cars – before escalating into a full border shutdown. A Mexican ambassador to the US later said that the country wants to cooperate with the US on immigration issues.

* PREVIEW: Nonfarm Payrolls (March 2019) are expected to revert to a more trend-like pace in March, following the sub-par Feb data (which was likely on idiosyncratic effects, analysts say). The jobless rate is seen remaining at 3.8%. Wage growth is seen moderating a touch, though would still be consistent with the recent pick-up. Click here for the full preview.

* INITIAL JOBLESS CLAIMS: Initial jobless claims fell to a new cycle low at 202k. "This is a very welcome surprise, coming hot on the heels of significant downward revisions to claims which suggested that the trend was flat rather than rising, as prior data suggested," Pantheon Macroeconomics said. "One week does not prove anything, but if this reading—the lowest since December 1969—is repeated, it would suggest that the trend is still falling." However, the consultancy says it is struggling with the idea given the slowdown in economic growth. "Note, though, that the data over the next few weeks, and perhaps this week’s number, are subject to distortions caused by the shifting date of Easter from year to year. As always, the trend is more important than single weekly numbers." News that Western forces were deploying more capital towards Tripoli shows provides an ominous signal that a conflict may be imminent.

* FED: Fed's Mester (non-voter) said it is possible that the FFR may need to move higher if the economy performs in line with Fed scenarios, but also says it is possible that the Fed is done with hikes for this cycle; she caveated this by saying she was biased to keeping rates on hold or moving them higher despite downside risks. Mester sees economic weakness in Q1 likely as temporary, however notes Europe and China are slowing. Fed's Harker (non-voter) said he is still in a "wait and see mode" and expects one rate hike "at most" in 2019 and one in 2020, but does not see a cut in either. He said he is paying attention to risks from the business investment outlook, global growth, trade developments, and the yield curve. On the US outlook, Harker said the US jobless rate is likely to fall to 3.5% this year before ticking up a few tenths of a point; he sees inflation averaging just above 2% in 2019 and 2020, which he does not believe to be a red flag.

* WTI FUTURES (K9) SETTLE USD 0.36 LOWER AT USD 62.10; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD 0.09 HIGHER AT USD 69.40. The crude complex failed to give up recent gains on Thursday, seemingly shrugging off the large build in US crude inventories, however Brent did perform better than its American counterpart, which traded rather flat. Some analysts have attributed the part closure of the key Houston shipping channel as a factor in preventing transportation of crude, hence leading to natural rises in crude stocks, given some fuel for bulls hoping this may be temporary. Elsewhere, unintentional supply constraint is looming over the Libya region again, where Eastern Libyan forces are said to be moving west towards Tripoli, “While an attempt to unify control of the country and potentially bring stability, we note that accomplishing this at the end of a gun also presents risks of ongoing conflict with crude oil production also in doubt,” analyst at Citigroup note.    

* SPX +0.21% at 2879, NDX -0.06% at 7541, DJI +0.64% at 26385. SECTORS: Energy +0.85%, Materials +1.00%, Industrials +0.61%, Communications -0.99%, Cons Discretionary +0.71%, Cons Staples +0.37%, Healthcare -0.24%, Financials +0.49%, Tech -0.44%, Telecoms +0.66%, Utilities -0.38%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Constellation Brands (STZ) outperformed on Thursday after reporting a beat on top and bottom line estimates as well as announcing the divesting of some of its wine and spirits assets, investors looked over its gloomy guidance. Tesla (TSLA) nosedived after disappointing results from its Q1 deliveries. Facebook (FB) caught a bid on the open following an upgrade at Guggenheim. Boeing (BA) benefitted from a note at Morgan Stanley saying that the worst case scenario is “off the table”; Morgan Stanley also caused Micron (MU) to dip lower, citing street estimates as too optimistic. Cowen analysts gave tailwinds to Netflix (NFLX), citing it as in a prime spot, and also Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), citing partnerships and digitalisation that will fuel growth. Office Depot (ODP) fell off a cliff on the back of a disappointing earnings outlook. Take-Two (TTWO) came under pressure as investors didn’t take to kindly to the announcement it would launch its Borderlands 3 videogame exclusively on the Epic Games store.

* US T-Note futures (M9) settle 1+ higher at 123-17+. According to the CME’s Fedwatch tool, the implied chance of a rate cut in 2019 still stands at over 50%. While this has certainly edged lower from periods in the last month where the chance was around 75% (implied by money market pricing), it still seems at odds with comments from Fed officials, who have generally been upbeat about the economy while acknowledging its slowing; many others have noted that as the tax-cut high fizzles out, growth was always expected to normalise. But there is still a lack of high profile Fed officials talking about cuts. Mester and Harker today both intimated the next move could be higher (non-voters). Perhaps the pricing is a result of comments from nominee Moore, who this week called for an immediate 50bps rate cut, and NEC director Kudlow, who echoed Moore’s remarks; then there is Trump's own preference for lower rates, and the criticism he often fires in the direction of the Fed. The latest on the Fed BOG, is that Trump is mulling nominating Herman Cain, who is a fan of former Fed chair Greenspan. Tomorrow’s payrolls data will be an important catalyst, but for different reasons than the Street may report: SocGen’s strategist Kit Juckes argues that a weak number could put the cat among the pigeons without telling us anything new, while a strong number wouldn’t be surprising unless it challenged the conclusions from other indicators. The key, Juckes says, is whether we are in an intra-cycle turn, like in 2016, or whether we are at the start of the end of the cycle; Juckes says he is in the latter camp, though notes that in 2006, the S&P 500 didn’t peak till later in the year, while IG CDS didn’t reach its tightest until 2007, suggesting there could be more juice in this market. In terms of the curve, action was very thin ahead of payrolls on Friday, and at settlement, curve spreads were a touch narrower.

* FX WRAP: Beware of news reports on slow market days that purport to offer firm reasons for market moves, while over exaggerating price moves. For instance, most of the FX wraps coming through to the desk have talked about a bloody day for the EUR following another dreadful report out of Germany which shows the manufacturing sector is in recession; at pixel time, the EUR is down around one-tenth of a percent. Nevertheless, it gave the USD a bid bias, though even that is up by around 0.25% as we head into Asia trade, and the buck was also support by a cautious risk environment ahead of the US jobs report on Friday. The pound did see a reasonable move – down around 0.7%; talks between the govt and opposition have not yielded any results yet, while talk of a long-extension and no deal is gaining traction. EMFX was a beneficiary of quiet trade, though the RUB was lower again as oil moved negative in later trade and talk of new sanctions from the US picked-up. the INR was also weaker, taking its cue from RBI rate cuts and possibly more looser policy ahead.  The Aussie was up, with iron ore prices once again providing some support.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar works its way off lows in the run up to NFP
content:
USD

Usd/G10 pairings are still relatively rangebound, but the Greenback has forged firmer gains vs several currency counterparts in wake of weekly claims data showing a decline to 202k from a revised 212k previously and vs an expected 216k. Although the week in question does not feed into the survey for the March BLS report due on Friday, the DXY gleaned some encouragement after Wednesday’s sub-forecast ADP tally and slowdown in the ISM non-manufacturing jobs component to grind off a near 97.000 base and probe above 97.300. Note, our full NFP primer is now available via the headline feed and Research Suite.

NZD/GBP

Ending the EU session as biggest losers having revisited recent highs just shy of 0.6800 and 1.3200 vs the Usd at various stages, but now eyeing this week’s lows sub-0.6750 and 1.3100 respectively. The Kiwi may have rattled by reports that a date for the eagerly-awaited Trump-Xi meeting to seal a trade deal is unlikely to be announced as soon as today, but also underperformed vs the AUD that is normally more sensitive to Chinese/global macro factors. However, Aud/Usd is holding up quite well on the 0.7100 handle amidst a major bank trade recommendation to go long of Aud/Nzd at market (1.0500 at the time and 1.0525 currently) with a profit target of 1.0900 and stop at 1.03000.

JPY/CAD/EUR/CHF

All on the back foot against the aforementioned bouncing Buck, albeit to varying degrees as Usd/Jpy extends the topside of its hitherto tight rage to just over 111.62 and into decent option expiries between 111.50-60 having breached the 200 DMA (111.49) a bit more convincingly. Similarly, the Loonie slipped to fresh lows vs its US peer near 1.3370 and only got a fleeting lift from firmer Canadian Ivey PMIs (SA and NSA), while the single currency and Franc both flirted with big figures at 1.1200 and parity, while Eur/Chf meandered just above 1.1200. Note, the Eur was not helped by more poor German data and another 2019 GDP forecast downgrade, along with more reports about the Italian Government revising its growth estimates for this year and conceding that the deficit will likely be 2.3-2.4% vs 2.04%.

EM

At last some positive news for the Try, as crude prices pulled back and S&P contended that Turkey’s rating is not under threat at present. In response, or sheer relief the Lira rebounded through 5.6000 vs the Dollar, in contrast to weakness in the Rouble that was undermined by a warning from the same ratings agency about a cut if the US imposes harsh and widespread sanctions on Russia. Usd/Rub back above 65.5500 and up to 65.6030 at one stage. Elsewhere, Usd/Inr is also firmer after the RBI cut its benchmark repo and reverse repo by ¼ point while maintaining a neutral stance.

  • Tesla (TSLA) – The electric automaker reported Q1 deliveries at 63K vehicles, which is down by 31% from last quarter

 

4th April 2019

EARNINGS

  • Constellation Brands (STZ) Q4 adj. EPS USD 1.84 vs. exp. USD 1.72, revenue USD 1.8bln vs. exp. USD 1.73bln. Sees FY20 adj. EPS USD 8.50-8.80 vs. exp. USD 9.44. Raises quarterly dividend by 1% to USD 0.75 per share. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech behemoth’s head of M&A, Adrian Perica, has been added to the co.’s executive leadership page on its website, hinting that it may be positioning itself for large deals. Elsewhere, BI reports that the co. is being sued over allegations that its batteries in the Apple Watch Series 3 swell after usage causing the screens to pop-out. (Newswires/BI)
  • Boeing (BA) – Ethiopian Airlines preliminary report from the 737 MAX jet crash showed that the pilots followed the recommended procedures given by Boeing and the FAA, but the jet’s nosediving persisted. WSJ reports that Boeing and the FAA are facing criticism from pilots over their unsatisfactory emergency instructions. (Newswires/WSJ)
  • Caterpillar (CAT) – UBS analyst Steven Fisher maintained his Sell rating and USD 125 PT on the industrials bellwether, citing a softening of replacement demand in 2020 after an acceleration in 2019. (Newswires)
  • Intel (INTC) – The chipmaker has missed deadlines for the development of its XMM 8160 5G modem for the 2020 iPhones (AAPL), where it is set to be the sole provider for the chips in 2020 iPhones. (Fast Company)
  • JPMorgan (JPM) – CEO Jamie Dimon in his annual letter said to shareholders that the co. sees Q1 net interest income to be flat compared to Q4 and adj. expenses to be up mid-single digits compared to Q1 2018. He added that Q1 markets revenue is expected to be down by low-double digits compared to Q4. Dimon says he would rather use capital for growth rather than share buybacks, and that the co. is prepared for but not predicting a recession. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • AT&T (T) – The network was proud to announce that Ookla determined that AT&T had the fastest US network in Q1 2019. (Newswires)
  • Bank of America (BAC) – The bank has said it will commit an additional USD 300bln by 2030 via its environmental initiative, expanding its exposure to low-carbon business activities. (Newswires)
  • Constellation Brands (STZ) – The beverages conglomerate is to divest c. 30 brands from its wine and spirits portfolio to E. & J. Gallo Winery, for a value of USD 1.7bln, where CEO Newland said this “will help enhance organizational focus on a more premium set of wine and spirits brands.” (Newswires)
  • Dominion (D) – The energy co.’s CEO said on Mad Money that the co. plans to slow the rate of dividends, starting next year, but is not considering cutting the dividend. (Newswires)

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – A week after being announced, almost half of the Google’s external AI ethics board have quit. (VOX)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retail giant is planning to relocate its whole worldwide operations team, several thousand employees, form Seattle to Bellevue by 2023, GeekWire reports. WSJ reports that luxury brands have stayed away from Amazon and favoured competitors such as Alibaba (BABA) and JD.com (JD), as they are not fond of their products being displayed alongside cheaper ones. CNBC reports that the retailer has been quietly removing promotional spots for its own private label products. (GeekWire/WSJ/CNBC)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media giant is paying the UK publication, The Telegraph, to include positive stories which defends Facebook on subjects such as terrorism, hate speech and cyber-bullying, BI reports. Elsewhere, the co.’s WhatsApp unit is launching a WhatsApp Business App for IOS globally in the coming weeks. (BI/Newswires)
  • Netflix (NFLX) – The streaming co. has amended its bylaws, where the added changes now permit that a shareholder, or a group of up to 20 shareholders, who own at least a three percent stake and have held it for three years can now nominate up to two board members for annual meeting proxy materials. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The electric automaker reported Q1 deliveries at 63K vehicles, which is down by 31% from last quarter, but up 110% YY; 50,900 Model 3s and 12,100 Model Ss and Xs. The co. said that due to large orders from Europe and China it had only delivered half of its orders by the near the end of the quarter, where deliveries will be shifted in Q2. On the back of this, JPM, JMP Securities, Canaccord and Wedbush lowered their price targets for the co. and Goldman reiterated its Sell rating and USD 210 price target. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • EnerSys (ENS) – The batteries manufacturer has been awarded a competitive USD 423.77mln contract for the supply of storage batteries to the US Army. (Newswires)
  • Fintech (FSV, FDC, FIS, WP, TSS, GPN) – MoffetNathanson analyst Lisa Ellis says that due to increasing e-commerce and digital payments in Europe, Asia and LatAm, M&A deals are more likely in the sector, especially following recent transactions such as Fiserv’s proposed merger with First Data, as well as Fidelity National Information Services’ merger with WorldPay. She cites a TSYS (TSS) and Global Payments (GPN) deal an "obvious, but true" option. (Newswires)
  • PG&E (PCG) – The Californian utilities co. has appointed Bill Johnson, six-year CEO of Tennessee Valley Authority, alongside 10 new board members, which investors Abrams Capital Management, Knighthead Capital Management and Redwood Capital Management have shown support for. (Newswires)
  • Pinduoduo (PDD) – The Chinese e-commerce platform reportedly spent excessively on sales and marketing, “wiping out” its top line. (FT)

subject: EU Commission Katainen says a hard Brexit is becoming increasingly possible as we do not know what the alternatives are, adds if there is no WA then that means there are few options available
RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 4th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European indices have traded lackluster this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C] as markets await US-China updates and ahead of key risk events
  • MPs marginally approved a bill preventing a no-deal Brexit, but rejected restricting extension date to before May 22nd & further indicative votes
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB Minutes, US Initial Jobless Claims, Fed's Williams, Mester & Harker

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded cautiously with the region tentative ahead of looming risk events and after a positive lead from Wall St. where US-China trade optimism kept stocks afloat despite poor ISM & ADP data. ASX 200 (-0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (Unch.) were subdued with broad weakness seen across all sectors in Australia as the post-budget euphoria faded and profit-taking set in following a 7-day win streak, while the Japanese benchmark was indecisive amid a choppy currency. Chinese markets were mixed ahead of an extended weekend in which the Hang Seng (-0.2%) stalled after it briefly rose above 30k for the first time since June last year, while the Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) was boosted on hopes US and China are nearing a trade deal and with reports also suggesting a Trump-Xi meeting date to sign off on a deal could be announced as early as today. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as prices tracked the recent weakness in T-notes and as Japanese stock markets held above water for most the session, while mixed results at the 30yr auction also failed to spur demand.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral for the week vs. last week's CNY 110bln net drain. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7055 (Prev. 6.7194)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He will meet with US President Trump after the trade discussions today, while it was also reported that US and Chinese officials are still discussing when their leaders can meet to sign off on a trade deal and that a meeting date could be announced as soon as Thursday according to sources familiar with the plans. (Newswires/WSJ)

China MOFCOM spokesman states that China & the EU are increasing the pace of bilateral investment talks. Will initiate measures to support car imports and markets for used cars. (Newswires)

US Agriculture Secretary Perdue says US-China trade talks are down to the last few days. Perdue also commented that the US wants binding China pledges which are enforced by tariffs with a target of 2025 for China to meet trade pledges, while the US also wants a timetable for China purchases and market access. (Newswires)

Indian Repo Rate 6.00% vs. Exp. 6.00% (Prev. 6.25%); RBI retained “neutral” stance. One member wanted to change stance to “accommodative”. RBI says output gap remains negative, domestic economy facing headwinds on a global front. (Newswires)

Fitch affirm India at BBB-, and state that outlook is stable. (Newswires)

US

Some on Special Counsel Mueller's team reportedly view their findings as more damaging for President Trump than Attorney General Barr revealed according to New York Times. Elsewhere, there were also reports that US House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Neal sent a letter to the IRS seeking President Trump's tax returns. (Newswires/NYT)

Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, dove) said he doesn't believe US economy is overheating or that the Fed needs to tap the brakes, while he added that the Fed should not react to noisy data by cutting interest rates now. (Newswires)

UK/EU   

UK lawmakers voted (313 ayes vs. 312 noes) to approve the EU Withdrawal Bill which requires UK PM May to seek an extension of Article 50 to prevent a no-deal Brexit. In terms of the key amendments, UK parliament rejected the Benn Amendment which would have held indicative votes on Monday after a tie of (310 vs. 310) and rejected Amendment 1 (123 ayes vs. 488 noes) which was tabled by Brexiteers and would have seeked to ensure Brexit occurs before May 22. (Newswires)

UK PM May could request a 9-month extension to Brexit during upcoming EU summit according to The Sun. In addition, it was also reported that 15 more Brexiteer Ministers including 5 from the Cabinet are said to be on the edge of resigning in a mass protest against PM May's softer Brexit bid, according to The Sun's Political Editor Tom Newton Dunn. (Newswires/The Sun)

UK Chancellor Hammond said Brexit delay will inevitably be long and UK will have to prepare to take part in European elections, while he added that the Cabinet is hoping UK will be allowed to leave the EU earlier if a deal is passed in the coming months. Furthermore, Hammond said there is a credible case for a confirmatory referendum which deserves to be voted on in Parliament but added that he is unsure if there is a majority for a second referendum, according to ITV's Peston. (Newswires/ITV)

DUP MP Donaldson seemed to hold out the prospect of the DUP backing a customs union, according to BBC's Northern Ireland correspondent. (BBC)

UK MPs are reportedly ready to sit as long as they need to force the Cooper bill on extending Article 50 through this week, there are suggestions that some may filibuster it in the House of Lords, according to BBC's Eardley. (Twitter)

Italy are to cut 2019 GDP forecast to 0.1% (Prev. 1.0%) and budget deficit set to rise to 2.30-2.40% (Prev. 2.04%) this year; according to sources. (Newswires)

German Construction PMI (Mar) 55.6 (Prev. 54.7)

German Industrial Orders MM Feb -4.2% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. -2.6%, Rev. -2.1%)

Turkish Central Bank has hiked swap sale limit to 40% (Prev. 30%) for transactions that are not matured. Turkish Central Bank has quadrupled the swap sales limit in 2 weeks. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

A subdued start to the fourth European session of the week with stocks treading water thus far [Eurostoxx 50 U/C] following a mixed Asia-Pac session, ahead of key risk events including the ECB minutes and US-Sino trade talks. The FTSE 100 (-0.6%) marginally lags in the equity-space as a slew of ex-divs [Direct Line (-5.0%), St James’ Place (-3.4%) and DS Smith (-2.4%)] coupled with a firmer Pound pressure the index. Broad-based losses are seen across European sectors, although energy names are faring slightly worse amidst marginal downside in the oil complex. In terms of individual movers, Commerzbank (+2.4%) trades near the top of the Stoxx 600 amid reports that UniCredit (-1.4%) may bid on the German bank if a Deutsche Bank (-1.7%) deal fails. Meanwhile, Software AG (+3.0%) shares were bolstered by a broker upgrade at UBS. On the flip side, Maersk (-11.2%) shares declined following the separate listing of its drilling unit.

Boeing (BA): In the preliminary Ethiopian crash report anti-stall software is not explicitly mentioned; Chief investigator says they cannot yet say if there is a structural problem with Max 8's. (Newswires)

Tesla (TSLA) Q1 vehicle output was approximately 77.1k vehicles vs. Prev. 86.6k Q/Q, Q1 deliveries 63.0k vehicles vs. Prev. 90.7k Q/Q. (Newswires)

FX

DXY - The Dollar index is holding around the 97.000 level within an extremely narrow 97.013-225 range, and symptomatic of the listless tone in the G10 currency markets overall after choppy trade from Monday through Wednesday amidst fluctuating risk on, off and on again sentiment. However, today and Friday offer some prospect of more decisive moves or at least price action if not clear direction, with the ECB Minutes, Fed speakers and NFP on the agenda.

GBP - The Pound remains underpinned as UK Parliament passed another motion to avoid a no deal Brexit and request that PM May go back to the EU seeking a further A 50 extension if no alternative is found to the WA by April 12 or May 22 (assuming no sudden change of heart and the current proposal with Brussels is accepted as the better of evils vs a CU). Cable has rebounded from yesterday’s sub or circa 1.3120 lows to retest 1.3200, but not quite as near the big figure this time as 21/30 DMA convergence around 1.3165 continues to exert some gravitational influence. Similarly, Eur/Gbp has retreated through 0.8550 towards 0.8500 again, though has not managed to get as close as it did on Wednesday.

JPY/EUR - Both firmer vs the Greenback, albeit fractionally given the relatively constrained trade noted above, with the Jpy inching higher within a 111.50-35 band and potentially capped by decent option expiry interest from 111.50-60 (1.3 bn) and the 200DMA (111.49). Meanwhile, the single currency continues to meet resistance around 1.1250 and has not been helped by abysmal German industrial orders data or confirmation that the country’s group of Economic Institutes has become the latest to slash the 2019 GDP to under 1%.

CHF/NZD/AUD/CAD – All underperforming, but again in context only marginally. Indeed, the Franc is meandering between 0.9987-72, Kiwi hovering from 0.6800 to 0.6773 and Aussie just keeping its head above 0.7100, and at this stage not looking likely to arouse expiry interest at 0.7140-50 in 1 bn. For choice, the Loonie is lagging against the backdrop of softer crude prices and back below 1.3350 ahead of Canada’s Ivey PMI.

EM - Literally no respite for the Lira it seems, as economic, fiscal and political issues continue to weigh on the currency and Turkish assets in general. Indeed, Usd/Try has nudged up to 5.6600 again after Wednesday’s mixed inflation data and another hike in swap limits, as investors eye next week’s Economic Program conscious of the fact that the CBRT may not be able to loosen its grip on the monetary policy reins given that headline CPI remains so high.

FIXED INCOME

Following a relatively lengthy phase of largely sideways trade, Bunds are looking perky again and leading fellow core bonds to fresh or a test of intraday highs. The 10 year German benchmark just topped out at 165.66, +26 ticks vs -21 ticks at one stage and Gilts are back to within a few ticks of their 128.50 Liffe best, while US Treasuries are also nudging overnight session peaks with the curve a tad flatter. In terms of a catalyst, marginal underperformance in Italian BTPs on the back of latest reports about a drastic cut in projected 2019 GDP and a wider deficit accordingly? Ahead, more pre-NFP proxies and a trio of Fed speakers including NY’s Williams.

COMMODITIES

The energy complex had consolidated following yesterdays advances and was edging lower for the majority of the session, though WTI & Brent futures have recently reverted much of this downside and are now just edging into positive territory for the day. Brent and WTI are currently trading around sesson highs of USD 69.34 and USD 62.50 respectively. Earlier in the session, Brent prices edged lower after hitting resistance at its 200 DMA around USD 69.60/bbl, meanwhile WTI remains north of its 200 DMA (USD 61.40/bbl). Elsewhere, spot gold (+0.1) trades lacklustre as markets are tentative ahead of the ECB minutes, US-China trade talks and NFP. It is also worth noting that investors are pulling money out of gold ETFs with around USD 153mln removed out of the USD 10bln VanEck Vectors Gold Miners ETF over the last five days. Meanwhile, copper (-0.3%) succumbs to the cautious risk tone but remains above its 100 WMA of just under USD 2.90/lb. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures saw its best day in seven-weeks, extending its record-breaking rally, as supply-side woes (largely from cyclones in Western Australia) and a pick-up in demand (steel mills replenishing stocks) boosted the base metal to a new peak of USD 103.49/tonne.

CME lowered NatGas Henry Hub futures margins by 10.8% to USD 1650/contract. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Markets hold fire as key risk events remain in sight - 4th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

A subdued start to the fourth European session of the week with stocks treading water thus far [Eurostoxx 50 -0.1%] following a mixed Asia-Pac session, ahead of key risk events including the ECB minutes and US-Sino trade talks. The FTSE 100 (-0.6%) marginally lags in the equity-space as a slew of ex-divs [Direct Line (-5.3%), St James’ Place (-3.0%) and DS Smith (-2.9%)] coupled with a firmer Pound pressure the index. Broad-based losses are seen across European sectors, although energy names are faring slightly worse amidst marginal downside in the oil complex. In terms of individual movers, Commerzbank (+2.7%) trades near the top of the Stoxx 600 amid reports that UniCredit (-1.2%) may bid on the German bank if a Deutsche Bank (-1.3%) deal fails. Meanwhile, Software AG (+3.2%) shares were bolstered by a broker upgrade at UBS. On the flip side, Maersk (-11%) shares declined following the separate listing of its drilling unit.

FX

DXY - The Dollar index is holding around the 97.000 level within an extremely narrow 97.013-120 range, and symptomatic of the listless tone in the G10 currency markets overall after choppy trade from Monday through Wednesday amidst fluctuating risk on, off and on-again sentiment. However, today and Friday offer some prospect of more decisive moves or at least price action if not clear direction, with the ECB Minutes, Fed speakers and NFP on the agenda.

GBP - The Pound is a marginal outperformer as UK Parliament passed another motion to avoid a no deal Brexit and request that PM May go back to the EU seeking a further A 50 extension if no alternative is found to the WA by April 12 or May 22 (assuming no sudden change of heart and the current proposal with Brussels is accepted as the better of evils vs a CU). Cable has rebounded from yesterday’s sub or circa 1.3120 lows to retest 1.3200, but not quite as near the big figure this time as 21/30 DMA convergence around 1.3165 continues to exert some gravitational influence. Similarly, Eur/Gbp has retreated through 0.8550 towards 0.8500 again, though has not managed to get as close as it did on Wednesday.

JPY/EUR - Both firmer vs the Greenback, albeit fractionally given the relatively constrained trade noted above, with the Jpy inching higher within a 111.50-35 band and potentially capped by decent option expiry interest from 111.50-60 (1.3 bn) and the 200DMA (111.49). Meanwhile, the single currency continues to meet resistance around 1.1250 and has not been helped by abysmal German industrial orders data or confirmation that the country’s group of Economic Institutes has become the latest to slash the 2019 GDP to under 1%.

CHF/NZD/AUD/CAD - All underperforming, but again in context only marginally. Indeed, the Franc is meandering between 0.9987-72, Kiwi hovering from 0.6800 to 0.6773 and Aussie just keeping its head above 0.7100, and at this stage not looking likely to arouse expiry interest at 0.7140-50 in 1 bn. For choice, the Loonie is lagging against the backdrop of softer crude prices and back below 1.3350 ahead of Canada’s Ivey PMI.

EM - Literally no respite for the Lira it seems, as economic, fiscal and political issues continue to weigh on the currency and Turkish assets in general. Indeed, Usd/Try has nudged up to 5.6600 again after Wednesday’s mixed inflation data and another hike in swap limits, as investors eye next week’s Economic Program conscious of the fact that the CBRT may not be able to loosen its grip on the monetary policy reins given that headline CPI remains so high.

FIXED INCOME

Following a relatively lengthy phase of largely sideways trade, Bunds are looking perky again and leading fellow core bonds to fresh or a test of intraday highs. The 10 year German benchmark just topped out at 165.66, +26 ticks vs -21 ticks at one stage and Gilts are back to within a few ticks of their 128.50 Liffe best, while US Treasuries are also nudging overnight session peaks with the curve a tad flatter. In terms of a catalyst, marginal underperformance in Italian BTPs on the back of latest reports about a drastic cut in projected 2019 GDP and a wider deficit accordingly? Ahead, more pre-NFP proxies and a trio of Fed speakers including NY’s Williams.

COMMODITIES

The energy complex is consolidating following yesterday’s advances and as the Dollar nurses some losses. WTI and Brent futures have been edging lower throughout Asia-Pac and European trade amid a lack of catalysts and a slightly sombre risk tone around the market, ahead of key risk events. Brent prices edged lower after hitting resistance at its 200 DMA around USD 69.60/bbl, meanwhile WTI remains north of its 200 DMA (USD 61.40/bbl). Elsewhere, spot gold (+0.1) trades lacklustre as markets are tentative ahead of the ECB minutes, US-China trade talks and NFP. It is also worth noting that investors are pulling money out of gold ETFs with around USD 153mln removed out of the USD 10bln VanEck Vectors Gold Miners ETF over the last five days. Meanwhile, copper (-0.3%) succumbs to the cautious risk tone but remains above its 100 WMA of just under USD 2.90/lb. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures saw its best day in seven-weeks, extending its record-breaking rally, as supply-side woes (largely from cyclones in Western Australia) and a pick-up in demand (steel mills replenishing stocks) boosted the base metal to a new peak of USD 103.49/tonne.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures buck firmer external leads
content: Notwithstanding BoE Governor Carney’s heightened concern about a no deal Brexit, and the fact that anything decided by UK Parliament still needs to be signed off by the EU, the latest HoC vote to seek a longer extension rather than face a cliff-edge on April 12 or May 22 has raised expectations/hopes of a softer departure. Hence, Gilts have resumed Liffe mainly on the back foot between 129.28-50 vs their previous 128.47 settlement price, with only minor traction coming from the post-German data rebound in Bunds (which incidentally gathered a bit more momentum earlier when the 10 year benchmark reached 165.57), while the Short Sterling strip has been 3 ticks adrift, though now 0.5-2 ticks offside.

subject: European equity movers this morning: Commerzbank (CBK GY) +3.5%; Daily Mail & General (DMG LN) +2.1%; Maersk (MAERSKB DC) -10%; Casino (CO FP) -4.2%; British American Tobacco (BATS LN) -1.4%; Unicredit (UCG IM) -1.3%; Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) -1.2%
Bunds: bolstered by bad German data
content: The 10 year German debt future has extended its recovery from opening and early Eurex lows that pushed the core Eurozone bond closer towards a band of resistance ahead of 165.00 in wake of a dire factory orders print from the bloc’s premier member state. The hard data effectively confirms weakness flagged in the corresponding PMI and has lifted Bunds to a 165.51 high from 165.28 initially and a 165.19 base vs yesterday’s 165.40 close, while the equivalent cash yield is flirting with parity or fractionally negative terrain again. It remains to be seen whether the Dax and other EU bourses also acknowledge the poor industrial orders release and retreat further than already anticipated via futures. Ahead, hefty supply via Spain and France may warrant some concession, but ECB minutes could be Thursday’s major regional highlight if more details about TLTRO3 and forward guidance is revealed.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

4th April 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded cautiously with the region tentative ahead of looming risk events and after a positive lead from Wall St. where US-China trade optimism kept stocks afloat despite poor ISM & ADP data. ASX 200 (-0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (Unch.) were subdued with broad weakness seen across all sectors in Australia as the post-budget euphoria faded and profit-taking set in following a 7-day win streak, while the Japanese benchmark was indecisive amid a choppy currency. Chinese markets were mixed ahead of an extended weekend in which the Hang Seng (-0.4%) stalled after it briefly rose above 30k for the first time since June last year, while the Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) was boosted on hopes US and China are nearing a trade deal and with reports also suggesting a Trump-Xi meeting date to sign off on a deal could be announced as early as today.

FTSE

EX-DIVS: Direct Line (DLG LN), Ferguson (FERG LN), Hikma (HIK LN), Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY LN), Melrose (MRO LN), Pearson (PSON LN), St James’ Place (STJ LN), DS Smith (SMDS LN), Smith’s Group (SMIN LN), Smith & Nephew (SN/ LN) and Taylor Wimpey (TW/ LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out today, trimming 11 points off the FTSE 100. (Newswires)

Tobacco Names – China Tobacco reportedly set to take on overseas competitors. (FT)

Gambling Names – UK advertising watchdog has found that 5 gambling names (Redbet, Multilott, Unibet, Playojo & Vikings Video Slot) broke advertising rules which prohibit gambling adverts from being targeted at under 18s. (Guardian)

Reckitt Benckiser (RB/ LN) – Co’s CEO is reportedly expected to resign by year-end, after once again being named one of the UK’s most overpaid executives. (Telegraph)

Anglo American (AAL LN) – Co’s CEO has stated that the benefits of mining for diamonds should not be underestimated, CEO also emphasised the measures the Co. are taking to improve the supervision of tailings dams. (FT)

HSBC (HSBA LN) – Advisory group ISS has highlighted concerns regarding Co’s pay arrangements and have described the guaranteed bonus scheme as being a ‘problematic issue’, adding that no clear guidelines are available regarding how/why these bonuses are earned. These comments come ahead of the Co’s pay policy, including the guaranteed bonus measure, going to a shareholder vote next week. (Guardian)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Intu Properties (INTU LN) – Co. will names Matthew Roberts as its new CEO after a nine-month search for a successor to David Fischel, according to Sky News. (Sky News)

BROKER MOVES

SAGE GROUP (SGE LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT CITI

RYANAIR (RYA LN) REITERATED OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

DAILY MAIL & GENERAL (DMGT LN) INITIATED OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

DAX

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) – Tata Steel (TATA IS) is proposing selling a Welsh plant in an attempt to get its GBP 13bln JV with Thyssenkrupp approved by the European Commission. Tata submitted the proposal at the start of the month, with a verdict from the EC expected within weeks. (The Telegraph) Separately, the German government are to reportedly provide a export guarantee for warships which are built by the Co. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY)/Commerzbank (CBK GY) - UniCredit (UCG IM) is reportedly preparing a rival offer for Commerzbank in the event that the Deutsche Bank deal fails.(FT) Separately, sources stated that Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank are divided over the pace of merger talks. Furthermore, reports stated that a preliminary decision on a merger between the German banks could be made as early as this weekend. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 4th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian indices were mixed with sentiment kept afloat by US-China trade optimism; notably, speculation around an imminent sign-off date for a deal
  • MPs narrowly approved a bill to prevent a no-deal Brexit, but rejected restricting extension date to before May 22nd & further indicative votes
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Industrial Orders, ECB Minutes, US Initial Jobless Claims, RBI Rate Decision, Fed's Williams, Mester & Harker, supply from Spain & France

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded cautiously with the region tentative ahead of looming risk events and after a positive lead from Wall St. where US-China trade optimism kept stocks afloat despite poor ISM & ADP data. ASX 200 (-0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (Unch.) were subdued with broad weakness seen across all sectors in Australia as the post-budget euphoria faded and profit-taking set in following a 7-day win streak, while the Japanese benchmark was indecisive amid a choppy currency. Chinese markets were mixed ahead of an extended weekend in which the Hang Seng (-0.4%) stalled after it briefly rose above 30k for the first time since June last year, while the Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) was boosted on hopes US and China are nearing a trade deal and with reports also suggesting a Trump-Xi meeting date to sign off on a deal could be announced as early as today. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as prices tracked the recent weakness in T-notes and as Japanese stock markets held above water for most the session, while mixed results at the 30yr auction also failed to spur demand.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral for the week vs. last week's CNY 110bln net drain. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7055 (Prev. 6.7194)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He will meet with US President Trump after the trade discussions today, while it was also reported that US and Chinese officials are still discussing when their leaders can meet to sign off on a trade deal and that a meeting date could be announced as soon as Thursday according to sources familiar with the plans. (Newswires/WSJ)

US Agriculture Secretary Perdue says US-China trade talks are down to the last few days. Perdue also commented that the US wants binding China pledges which are enforced by tariffs with a target of 2025 for China to meet trade pledges, while the US also wants a timetable for China purchases and market access. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK lawmakers voted (313 ayes vs. 312 noes) to approve the EU Withdrawal Bill which requires UK PM May to seek an extension of Article 50 to prevent a no-deal Brexit. In terms of the key amendments, UK parliament rejected the Benn Amendment which would have held indicative votes on Monday after a tie of (310 vs. 310) and rejected Amendment 1 (123 ayes vs. 488 noes) which was tabled by Brexiteers and would have seeked to ensure Brexit occurs before May 22. (Newswires)

UK PM May will reportedly pave the way for a longer extension next week in the event she cannot secure her deal and the UK would participate in European Parliament elections in that scenario, according to a Telegraph reporter. (Telegraph) UK PM May could request a 9-month extension to Brexit during upcoming EU summit according to The Sun. In addition, it was also reported that 15 more Brexiteer Ministers including 5 from the Cabinet are said to be on the edge of resigning in a mass protest against PM May's softer Brexit bid, according to The Sun's Political Editor Tom Newton Dunn. (Newswires/The Sun)

UK Chancellor Hammond said Brexit delay will inevitably be long and UK will have to prepare to take part in European elections, while he added that the Cabinet is hoping UK will be allowed to leave the EU earlier if a deal is passed in the coming months. Furthermore, Hammond said there is a credible case for a confirmatory referendum which deserves to be voted on in Parliament but added that he is unsure if there is a majority for a second referendum, according to ITV's Peston. (Newswires/ITV)

There were initial reports that UK opposition Labour leader Corbyn said talks with PM May went "very well" and expects more talks with the PM soon according to Daily Mirror's Pippa Crerar. However, there were later reports citing UK government sources that talks with Labour were not as productive as previously stated in which one source suggested it "did not go well". (Twitter/BuzzFeed)

DUP MP Donaldson seemed to hold out the prospect of the DUP backing a customs union, according to BBC's Northern Ireland correspondent. (BBC)

BoE Governor Carney said the risk of a no-deal is alarmingly high in which he warned could happen by accident and said that suggestions a no-deal could be managed are absolute nonsense. Furthermore, BoE's Carney said he will do everything to support the economy in the event of a no-deal Brexit but suggested the financial sector was not among the worries in a no-deal scenario, while he added that he would absolutely not stay in his post past the planned January 2020 departure. (Newswires/Sky News) 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was softer and eyed the 97.00 level to the downside in the wake of the prior day’s double whammy of poor data including a 19-month low US ISM Non-Manufacturing and with ADP Employment falling short of estimates ahead of the upcoming Non-Farm Payrolls. The subdued USD benefitted its major counterparts, although upside was limited by a lack of fresh catalysts in which EUR/USD oscillated within the prior day’s tight range, while GBP/USD was mildly supported after MPs voted to approve the Cooper-Letwin bill. Elsewhere, risk sensitive currencies AUD, NZD and JPY were indecisive amid a similar overnight sentiment and due to lack of data releases, while the PBoC took a swipe at the greenback and strengthened its fix accordingly.

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities trade was lacklustre amid the indecisive overnight risk tone which saw WTI crude futures remain flat throughout the session, while this week’s bearish inventory data including a surprise build of over 7.2mln barrels in headline DoE crude stockpiles ensured a breather from oil’s recent hot streak. Elsewhere, gold prices were uneventful with only minimal gains seen amid a softer greenback and copper trade was also uninspiring as it largely reflected the cautious risk sentiment.

CME lowered NatGas Henry Hub futures margins by 10.8% to USD 1650/contract. (Newswires) 

US

The constructive risk environment resulted in higher yields. The usual suspects -- optimism about the prospects of a China/US trade deal, less chance of no deal Brexit, decent services PMIs out of china and Europe, and a decent retail sales report out of the latter -- were cited, and the TPLEX was happy to look through a sub-par ADP report, and a mixed non-manufacturing ISM. Indeed, growth concerns have ebbed slightly, which is also reflected in the 3m/10yr spread remaining positive. Major curve spreads were a touch steeper. US T-note futures (M9) settled 8+ lower at 123-16.

US administration officials are said to have studied border closing options regarding the US/Mexico border in which options include a partial shutdown, while there were comments from White House spokeswoman Schlapp that progress has been made on the Mexico border issue. (Newswires)

Some on Special Counsel Mueller's team reportedly view their findings as more damaging for President Trump than Attorney General Barr revealed according to New York Times. Elsewhere, there were also reports that US House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Neal sent a letter to the IRS seeking President Trump's tax returns. (Newswires/NYT)

Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, dove) said he doesn't believe US economy is overheating or that the Fed needs to tap the brakes, while he added that the Fed should not react to noisy data by cutting interest rates now. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mixed amid US-China trade hopes and overnight profit taking
content:
Asia equity markets trade cautious with the region tentative ahead of the looming risk events and after a positive lead from Wall St. where US-China trade optimism kept stocks afloat despite poor ISM & ADP data. ASX 200 (-0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) are mixed with broad weakness seen across all sectors in Australia as the post-budget euphoria fades and profit taking sets in following a 7-day win streak, while the Japanese benchmark is higher but with gains limited amid a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Chinese markets are also varied ahead of an extended weekend with the Hang Seng (-0.4%) stalling after it briefly rose above 30k for the first time since June last year, while the Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) is boosted on hopes US and China are nearing a trade deal and with reports suggesting a Trump-Xi meeting date to sign off on a deal could be announced as early as today.

In FX markets, the DXY is softer and eyes the 97.00 level to the downside in the wake of the prior day’s double whammy of poor data including a 19-month low US ISM Non-Manufacturing and with ADP Employment also falling short of estimates ahead of the upcoming Non-Farm Payrolls. The subdued USD has benefitted its major counterparts, although upside is limited by a lack of fresh catalysts with EUR/USD oscillating within the prior day’s tight range, while GBP/USD was mildly supported after MPs voted to approve the Cooper-Letwin bill which seeks to avert the UK crashing out of the EU without a deal on April 12th. The bill which just about passed by the tightest possible margin of 1 vote (313 ayes vs. 312 noes), requires UK PM May to seek an extension of Article 50 to prevent a no-deal Brexit and will now go to the House of Lords, while MPs had also rejected Amendment 1 which was tabled by Brexiteers and would have restricted the Brexit date to before May 22nd. Elsewhere, risk sensitive currencies AUD, NZD and JPY are indecisive amid a similar overnight sentiment and due to lack of data releases, while the PBoC took a swipe at the greenback and strengthened its fix accordingly.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower with prices tracking the recent weakness in T-notes and as Japanese stock markets just about held above water, while participants are also sidelined ahead of a 30yr auction later.

Trade

US and Chinese officials are still discussing when their leaders can meet to sign off on a trade deal and a meeting date could be announced as soon as Thursday, according to sources familiar with the plans. (Newswires)

US Agriculture Secretary Perdue said US-China trade talks are down to the last few days. Perdue also commented that the US wants binding China pledges which are enforced by tariffs with a target of 2025 for China to meet trade pledges, while the US also wants a timetable for China purchases and market access. (Newswires)

US NEC Director Kudlow said that we are not there yet on a deal with China but hope to get closer this week, while he also commented that no decisions have been made yet regarding potential auto tariffs as the 90-day review period could be extended. (Newswires)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He will meet with US President Trump after the trade discussions on Today. (Newswires)
